title: Jollof Rice
summary: A classic West African rice dish cooked in a rich tomato sauce with spices.
instructions: Blend tomatoes, peppers, and one onion into a smooth paste.
Heat oil in a pot, sauté sliced onions, then add tomato paste and fry for 2 minutes.
Add the blended mixture and fry until the oil separates.
Season with thyme, curry, and salt.
Add chicken stock and bring to a boil.
Stir in the rice, reduce heat, and cover tightly.
Cook on low heat until rice is tender and liquid absorbed.

title: Egusi Soup
summary: A hearty Nigerian soup made with ground melon seeds, vegetables, and meat or fish.
ingredients: 2 cups chopped spinach or ugu leaves
instructions: Blend egusi with a little water into a thick paste.
Heat palm oil in a pot, then fry the egusi paste for 5–7 minutes.
Add blended onions and pepper mixture, stir and cook.
Add meat, stockfish, crayfish, and stock/water.
Simmer until meat is tender.
Stir in the vegetables and cook for another 5 minutes.

title: Suya
summary: A popular Nigerian street food made with spicy grilled beef skewers.
instructions: Soak skewers in water for 30 minutes.
Thread beef slices onto skewers.
Rub with oil and coat with suya spice mix.
Grill over hot charcoal or in the oven until cooked through.
Serve hot with onions, tomatoes, and cabbage.

title: Moi Moi
summary: A steamed Nigerian pudding made from blended beans, peppers, and spices.
instructions: Blend beans, peppers, and onion into a smooth paste.
Add oil, seasoning, and salt; mix well.
Pour mixture into greased ramekins or moi moi leaves.
Add sliced boiled eggs if using.
Steam for 45–60 minutes until firm.
